I should get one too. I note that the reply's author seems to think 
that a=
 Japanese art sword potentially worth tens or hundreds of 
thousands of dol=
lars is a dangerous weapon that needs to be locked up. 
In the past 20 or s=
o years in Victoria, how many attacks with katana 
have been recorded? How =
many with kitchen knives? Perhaps these should 
be locked up too. Sounds li=
ke government regulators running amuck.

Gordon

> =A0 Dear Mr Hoyle
>
> =A0 Comments on the Proposed Contr=
ol of Weapons (Amendment) Regulations 
> 2003
>
> =A0 Thank you for your em=
ail of 14 August 2003 to Mr Chris Shea of the
> =A0 Department of Justice r=
egarding the proposed Control of Weapons
> =A0 (Amendment) Regulations 2003=
.
>
> =A0 Your views have been noted and will be considered by the Minister=
 for
> =A0 Police and Emergency Services when assessing what action to take=
 on 
> the
> =A0 proposed Regulations.
>
> =A0 I would note that the propos=
ed Regulations propose to make swords a
> =A0 "prohibited weapon". The lawf=
ul use and possession of a "prohibited
> =A0 weapon" requires an Approval f=
rom the Chief Commissioner of Police 
> (for
> =A0 which a fee is charged).=
 Persons may be exempted from this 
> requirement
> =A0 by the Governor-in-=
Council. A person, therefore, under the proposed
> =A0 Regulations, could s=
till lawfully own and possess a sword if, for
> =A0 example, they obtained =
an Approval to do so from the Chief 
> Commissioner
> =A0 of Police.
>
> =
=A0 The proposed Regulations will not necessitate destruction of swords. 
>=
 In
> =A0 the event that the proposed Regulations come into operation, pers=
ons 
> in
> =A0 possession of a sword who do not obtain an Approval from th=
e Chief
> =A0 Commissioner of Police and who do not fall under an exemption=
 
> granted by
> =A0 the Governor-in-Council could dispose of their weapons=
 through, for
> =A0 example, an authorised weapons trader.
>
> =A0 The Regu=
latory Impact Statement (RIS) which assesses the impact of 
> the
> =A0 pro=
posed Regulations has been publicly released and I attach a copy 
> of
> =
=A0 the RIS for your information. Should you wish to make a further
> =A0 s=
ubmission on the proposed Regulations after reading the RIS (the
> =A0 prop=
osed Regulations themselves are at Attachment 1 to the RIS) you
> =A0 would=
 be most welcome to do so. The closing date for submissions is
> =A0 Monday=
 8 September 2003. Details on how to make a submission can be
> =A0 found i=
n the RIS.
>
> =A0 Further copies of the Regulatory Impact Statement can be=
 accessed on 
> the
> =A0 internet at www.justice.vic.gov.au
>
> =A0 Thank =
you for raising your views with the Department of Justice.
>
> =A0 Yours si=
ncerely

cy
